issue.title: Test case failures in Python 3.8 (CPython master)
issue.body:
I ran the test suite against the CPython master branch and I can see some test failures (Some of them are related to pip and pyparsing which have upstream issues). I have attached a log file of the pytest output that might be helpful. Some of them are easy. Since PyCon India is coming up with a DevSprint proposal let me know if I need to file them as separate bugs so that you can use the sprint to fix minor incompatibilities in Python 3.7 and above.
Log file : coala-pytest.log
Thanks for Coala and best wishes for the sprint!

issue.title: Add test cases for language definitions
issue.body:
If I recall correctly, we don't have test cases for language definitions. https://github.com/coala/coala/tree/master/coalib/bearlib/languages/definitions

issue.title: Discard ** in ignore = foo/**
issue.body:
An ignore glob of ignore = foo/** will walk the entire structure of foo/, which is silly.
That is #3655 .
But a quicker problem to solve : ignore = foo/** can be rewritten as ignore = foo/ and suddenly it doesnt walk foo/ .
coala should recognise foo/** in the ignore and warn the user , and then remove the**` internally.

issue.title: TestUtilities.execute_coala should check for timeouts
issue.body:
If there was a timeout during a test using execute_coala, pytest-timeout will emit Failed: Timeout >35.0s (number may change) and the timeout failure will be lost inside execute_coala/bear_test_module.
The test module will continue with the assertions, and cause various errors, as these coala output will be in a strange incomplete state.
This is one of the problems affecting #5571 and #5390
A quick workaround is to detect Failed: Timeout is stderr inside execute_coala and re-raise the problem with the complete stderr and stdout for debugging purposes.

issue.title: Python 3.3 unsupported check failing due to pytest 3.6.1 not available for that version
Undeclared coalib dependency on pytest-timeout
issue.body:
coalib currently depends on pytest-timeout, which isnt listed as a dependency in requirements.txt
$ git grep pytest coalib/
coalib/testing/LocalBearTestHelper.py:import pytest
coalib/testing/LocalBearTestHelper.py:    @pytest.mark.timeout(timeout)

This was done in 328bce6, and released in 0.9.0.
It originally came from coala/coala-bears@9d02f80
We would not want to add pytest-timeout or even pytest in the dependencies of coalib, as that makes any enviroment with coala dicate the test environment versions that the coala user must use, which may conflict with their own needs.
Possibly we need to move the test helpers to a separate repo, in order to avoid our test needs poluting the environment of our users.

issue.title: Create 'unsupported' language definitions for languages which do not use `\` as escape sequence
issue.body:
https://gitlab.com/coala/coala-utils/issues/64 shows that escape char \ is hard-wired into many functions and can not be easily removed.
To prevent bugs, we need coalang files for languages which do not use \ as the escape character, and those files need to clearly indicate that the language is not supported, with a comment explaining why.

issue.title: Result.py: Add docstring regarding the case that line or column is None
issue.body:
The output generated by coala can have line being None or column being None.
column = None means there is an error with the whole line.
line = None means the whole file. The reason behind it is that it's an unknown line means it can occur anywhere in the file.
All combinations with None values and numbers for line and column are allowed, except line=None and column=<some number>
This should be clarified in the documentation.
(ref: http://api.coala.io/en/latest/coalib.results.html#module-coalib.results.Result)

issue.title: Shouldn't be getting Executing section cli... when [cli] is empty
"filters" rewrite
issue.body:
Foremost,
[['language', 'c', 'java'], ['can_fix', 'syntax']]

is just wrong on every level.
Very worst case it should be tuples, not lists.
However it should be a dict, or OrderedDict if the order matters.
{'language': ['c', 'java'], 'can_fix': 'syntax'}

And better yet it should be a proper class, so that it can be used in type annotations.
In some places this 'structure' is given argument name filters, which hints it may contain multiple items.
In other places (e.g. apply_filter) it is filter_name.
And for is_valid_filter, the arg name is filter, which is a builtin function.

issue.title: Remove implementation of SpaceConsistencyTestBear
issue.body:
SpaceConsistencyTestBear contains an old algorithm of the SpaceConsistencyBear.
And there are five tests which depend on the output of its algorithm.
When the run method is replaced with pass, these tests fail:
FAIL tests/coalaCITest.py::coalaCITest::test_limit_files_affirmative
FAIL tests/coalaCITest.py::coalaCITest::test_show_patch
FAIL tests/coalaCITest.py::coalaCITest::test_show_patch_debug
FAIL tests/coalaTest.py::coalaTest::test_run_coala_no_autoapply
FAIL tests/coalaTest.py::coalaTest::test_run_coala_no_autoapply_debug

But more importantly, some unexpected parts of the codebase suddenly have no coverage.
coalib/coala_main.py                                                  104      1     48      1    99%   207, 206->207
coalib/output/ConsoleInteraction.py                                   337      1    156      1    99%   296, 287->296
coalib/results/result_actions/ShowPatchAction.py                       72      2     28      1    97%   104-107, 103->104

That means those lines of code are being indirectly tested by the inner workings of the bear.
These lines of code all need specific tests which are not based on large, old and convoluted algorithm of a bear.
They should have tiny neat little bears which are very simple and do only enough to activate those lines of code, and do it directly.

issue.title: In `ask_for_action_and_apply()`, if `apply_single` is non-False, function should return when match is found
issue.body:
In the function ask_for_action_and_apply() in ConsoleInteraction.py, if the apply_single parameter is non-False, then the for loop inside it iterates through the entire metadata_list before returning False.
IMHO we should include a break statement inside the if block (which is in the for loop) such that the function may return after a match is found because there is no need to go through the remaining actions in metadata_list.

issue.title: argparse.ArgumentParser is wrongly named ArgParser several times
issue.body:
(In doc strings)
Realized while reviewing: #4161 (comment)
> grep -R ArgParser coalib
coalib/coala.py:from coalib.parsing.DefaultArgParser import default_arg_parser
coalib/coala_main.py:    :param arg_parser:              Instance of ArgParser that is used to parse
coalib/coala_main.py.orig:    :param arg_parser:              Instance of ArgParser that is used to parse
coalib/misc/BuildManPage.py:            --parser=coalib.parsing.DefaultArgParser:default_arg_parser
coalib/parsing/CliParsing.py:from coalib.parsing.DefaultArgParser import default_arg_parser
coalib/parsing/CliParsing.py:    :param arg_parser:                  Instance of ArgParser that is used to
coalib/parsing/DefaultArgParser.py:    This function creates an ArgParser to parse command line arguments.
coalib/parsing/DefaultArgParser.py.orig:    This function creates an ArgParser to parse command line arguments.
coalib/settings/ConfigurationGathering.py:    :param arg_parser:  An ``ArgParser`` object.
coalib/settings/ConfigurationGathering.py:    :param arg_parser:       Instance of ArgParser that is used to parse

But actually argparse.ArgumentParser is meant there. So those occurrences should be changed accordingly to clearly know what is meant. Otherwise it looks like some coala-internal ArgParser class
@Udayan12167 @supergr35 @JohnS-01

issue.title: Replace pytest-timeout with pytest-faulthandler
issue.body:
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pytest-faulthandler activates on a timeout, but dumps out much more useful info.
Not sure we want this, as mostly our timeouts are network timeouts, and the cause is fairly self-evident.
See docker timeout issues.
Keeping this issue open as a place to record any new timeouts we encounter, to see if there is occasions we need more info than pytest-timeout provides.

issue.title: CommitBear: Check proper use of `https` when referencing issues
issue.body:
https://github.com/coala/coala-bears/blob/master/bears/vcs/CommitBear.py#L360 matches links and tags, e.g. fix #123, fix https://github.com
This would also pass the test Closes http://github.com. However, this would not trigger GitHub autolinked reference feature. The commit message should be Closes https://github.com instead.
For those who are not familiar with autolinked reference feature, I did a simple experiment. I created an issue first li-boxuan/github-playground#1
Then I create a pr, aiming to close that issue. See commit message https://github.com/li-boxuan/github-playground/pull/2/commits. However, after this pr gets merged, it doesn't close the corresponding issue automatically.
Finally, this pr https://github.com/li-boxuan/github-playground/pull/3/commits closes the corresponding issue automatically when it's merged. Check commit messages carefully to see the difference.
That means we should check proper usage of https, at least for GitHub. Not sure if GitLab has similar features.

issue.title: Create git-bug project
issue.body:
https://github.com/MichaelMure/git-bug cc @MichaelMure who has agreed to mentor.
Initial concept is bidirectional sync to GitHub issues with support for bridge impersonating multiple users, e.g. so corobo could be used to create issues as the person who used the bot (or maybe gitmate)
Another idea is GitLab issues support.
Another is a meta-git-bug for handling lots of projects, e.g. super repo with subtrees/submodules/etc of git-bug repos , or housing many GitHub sync'd repos of issue in a single git-bug repo
Ultimately this needs to be quite a broad project definition at this stage as many medium sized enhancements planned now might be completed before GSoC begins in 2019
Also worth investigating is git-appraise .

issue.title: Add configuration support
issue.body:
#1 is going to need to include configurability, so that repos with different structure can work in different ways.  i.e. we need to at least support @philschatz 's label system and derived gh-board layout, and support what @ryanprior likes, and what @coala needs, so that our patches will be able to make it back through the forks to the main repo (c.f. #2 )
There is one existing configuration item upstream, which is 'SAMPLE_REPOS' , and coala has added 'REPOSITORIES' for the pre-fetching.  I am surprised that there are no forks which have modified this (c.f. #5), as that seems like a logical easy way to improve the front page (c.f. #3).
Including configuration in the master branch causes forks to diverge.  We need to avoid that.
Some options for where to put the configuration:

the wiki
a different branch
an issue ;-)

Or, the configuration could be all derived from GitHub, if we ignore SAMPLE_REPOS. (and if we build a way to easily configure the front page, nobody will try to abuse this anyway.)  It will increase build time to extract an ideal layout based on GitHub org/repo metadata.  Also fetching the list of repos for an org requires an extra scope which orgs may not want in their Travis env vars, and if they use secure vars in the .travis.yml , their fork diverges.

issue.title: Do not error hard because a dependency of a bear has been updated
issue.body:
Currently, upon a simple load of bears, we implicitly check every single dependency to see if it's exactly as any given bear hard pins to antequated versions and fail hard if you are even slightly off. I don't see a reason this should be the case as this is Python; it's not coala's concern whether I've installed a later isort version than it expects, especially not at runtime.
This simple fix merely resolves each entrypoint instead, which is really what we're trying to do anyway.

issue.title: LocalBearTestHelper: Decommission timeout
issue.body:
LocalBearTestHelper had an undeclared dependency on pytest-timeout
so it would not work unless the user had install pytest-timeout.
None of our bear test suites use this timeout argument, as the
timeout set in their repo configuration is sufficient.
Fixes #5508

issue.title: Release notes now published at api docs
issue.body:
Release Notes are now published at api docs.
I was not familiar with reStructuredText.
I was initially trying to add Release Notes in
.. toctree::
   :caption: Home
   :hidden:

   Welcome <self>
   Homepage <http://coala.io/#/home>
   Release Notes <release_notes>
   Code of Conduct <http://coala.io/coc>
but it was giving out every title in this toctree, which is not suitable so I shifted Release Notes to it's own toctree.
Also to commit release_notes.rst i have to exclude it from .gitignore.
Closes: #5724

comments.bodyText:
Ok, so my understanding is you have already performed partial conversion to a dict based filter structure. A few remarks here:

Use OrderedDicts, filtering order is important here.
Use tuples for holding args, not lists.
Do not partially convert the filters, you should rather have all the filter args as tuples. {'language': ('c', 'java'), 'can_fix': ('syntax',), 'section_tags': ('save',)} otherwise it will force all the other unrelated methods to handle this case.

comments.bodyText:
When running test_jinja2_templating (due to coala/coala-bears#2678) which isnt the best of test approaches, but far from the worst, here are my error results
>               raise AssertionError(messages)
E               AssertionError: 'Usin[68 chars]o XSS. Ensure autoescape=True to mitigate XSS vulnerabilities.' != 'Usin[68 chars]o XSS. Use autoescape=True to mitigate XSS vulnerabilities.'
E               - Using jinja2 templates with autoescape=False is dangerous and can lead to XSS. Ensure autoescape=True to mitigate XSS vulnerabilities.
E               ?                                                                                ^^ --
E               + Using jinja2 templates with autoescape=False is dangerous and can lead to XSS. Use autoescape=True to mitigate XSS vulnerabilities.
E               ?                                                                                ^
E                : message_base mismatch.

../coala/coalib/testing/LocalBearTestHelper.py:136: AssertionError

Now how can I work out which of the five Result that was about?
This entire test system is fundamentally flawed.
test helpers should help diagose, not help write tests which are unable to be diagnosed.
If I change it to assert sorted(bear_output) == sorted(results), I see nothing because these Comparable objects are impossible for pytest to automatically inspect dynamically.  And self.assertCountEqual has also been busted: the output is a mess.  We are breaking the standard Python testing tools, and replacing them with something less helpful.
So at the moment, with pytest and unittest builtin systems not working on Result objects, we are reliant on this Comparable class and this helper to actually help decode the problem.  It doesnt do that before this patch, and this patch doesnt make it much better.

comments.bodyText:
these tests now rely on the output of pytest - see note above about capturing the assertion and converting it into a string.
That isnt helpful.
And these test cases are not helpful.
What we need are tests of multiple complicated Result objects, and showing that the error message is helpful for real scenarios.
And our messages should not use pytest's messages, because they are dumb -- they are automatic and can not know the context of the situation, or know what the bear debugger needs to see in order to be able to diagnose the problem.

comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@
+"""
+The core package provides an API for coala's NextGen-Core.
+
+The ``Core`` module is responsible for maintaining sessions for coala's
+execution and also running the tasks offloaded by the bears. The ``Bear``
+module provides a base class for all the NextGen Bears.
+
+``FileBear`` provides a Bear base class to parallelize tasks for each file.
+``ProjectBear`` on the other hand provides a base class for bears that run on
+the whole codebase. ``DependencyBear`` is a Bear base class that parallelizes
+tasks for dependency results.
+
+The ``DependencyTracker`` module registers and
+manages dependencies between objects. The circular dependency errors are
+handled by ``CircularDependencyError``. The ``Graphs`` detects cyclicity
+in dependency graphs and raises ``CircularDependencyError`` if found.
+
+``PersistentHash`` module generates a unique hash for every task object
+first by pickling them and then using the pickled object to generate a sha1
+hash. These persistent hashes can then be used for caching results.

@jayvdb updated.
Not sure why appveyor is failing though. I also don't see a rebuild button on appveyor is there no way to re run appveyor jobs except for a force push?

Not sure why appveyor is failing though. I also don't see a rebuild button on appveyor is there no way to re run appveyor jobs except for a force push?

Only admins have access to rebuild button. Go for force push.

Any time you see timeout is the log , assume it is our intermittent timeout problem, which is complicated by #5674 .  On AppVeyor, force push is all you can do until we get corobo back online and implement job restart commands in corobo.  But dont feel like you have to keep force pushing to get it green - if travis or circle pass, a note that appveyor timeouted is enough for us to keep the PR in the review queue even if appveyor is red.

issue.title: LocalBearTestHelper.py: Inherit from `BaseTestHelper`
issue.body:
This adds BaseTestHelper class, base class of all bears'
tests, to the LocalBearTestHelper.
Related to https://gitlab.com/coala/GSoC/GSoC-2018/issues/332
Closes #5501

comments.bodyText:
this is a backwards incompatible change.
all test classes in the bears, and anywhere else that has used LocalBearTestHelper, become broken if this is merged.  They all need to be rewritten, just like LocalBearTestHelper in this patch has needed to be completely rewritten.
Most features of pytest that we want to use co-exist nicely with unittest classes.
https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/master/doc/en/unittest.rst#pytest-features-in-unittesttestcase-subclasses
https://pypi.org/project/pytest-restrict/ explicitly supports unittest classes; that is what it is used for ... enforcing unittest classes when Django developers are using pytest, and should be using their customised Django unittest sub-classes.
That said, it is in the cEP (https://github.com/coala/cEPs/pull/149/files#diff-f29c16068974a5d9aff2fdeb6295bfdeR51), and we can deal with bears being broken while it is being patched, so this is feasible, but it is not desirable IMO without a good reason for why we are unnecessarily creating a breakage.

         return bear_output
 
 
-class LocalBearTestHelper(unittest.TestCase):
+class LocalBearTestHelper(BaseTestHelper):

comments.bodyText:
Two of the features I find most useful, namely parametrization and fixtures, do not work with unittest. That's why we want to get rid of it.
But I see the difficulty of introducing this change into an existing test suite. @sangamcse do you think it's feasible to keep the unittest dependency for now and still use the base class?

comments.bodyText:
@NiklasMM , fixtures do work, with a slightly different mechanism for some types of fixtures.
see https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/master/doc/en/unittest.rst#mixing-pytest-fixtures-into-unittesttestcase-subclasses-using-marks
and git grep fixture tests in coala-core repo.
wrt parameterisation, and even fixtures, I didnt see the rationale given in the cEP for how those will be used to improve bear testing.  I would argue that https://github.com/wolever/parameterized is as good a solution which works well for all test frameworks.  We already have a complex set of pytest plugins, and already use testfixtures, so an additional test dependency isnt a new complexity problem.
Anyway, my intention isnt to re-litigate that.  I am only commenting because of the huge breakage.
Leaving the existing unittest class as-is, and deprecating it, will reduce the risk substantially.  And then at the end of the project the huge rewrite of bear tests can happen, and it wont matter if there are some bear tests which are not migrated to pytest-only style for reasons not yet predicted.
If the immediate goal is only to enforce a common test base class, that can be achieved by changing this class to inherit from both:
class LocalBearTestHelper(BaseTestHelper, unittest.TestCase):
    ...

issue.title: [WIP] GlobalBearTestHelper.py: Add support
issue.body: Closes #4884

comments.bodyText: not defined
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,66 @@
+import os.path
+
+from contextlib import contextmanager
+
+from coalib.bears.GlobalBear import GlobalBear
+from coalib.testing.BaseTestHelper import BaseTestHelper
+
+
+@contextmanager
+def execute_bear(bear, *args, **kwargs):
+    try:
+        bear_output_generator = bear.execute(*args, **kwargs)
+        assert (bear_output_generator is not None
+                ), 'Bear returned None on execution\n'
+        yield bear_output_generator
+    except Exception as err:
+        msg = []
+        while not bear.message_queue.empty():
+            msg.append(bear.message_queue.get().message)
+        raise AssertionError(str(err) + ' \n' + '\n'.join(msg))
+    return list(bear_output_generator)
+
+
+def get_test_path(test_dir,
+                  file):
+    return os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__),
+                        test_dir, file)
+
+
+def get_results(global_bear,
+                test_dir,
+                file_dict,
+                settings={}):
+    for file in file_dict:
+        with get_test_path(test_dir, file) as fname, \
+            execute_bear(global_bear, fname, **settings
+                         ) as bear_output:
+            return bear_output
+
+
+class GlobalBearTestHelper(BaseTestHelper):
+    """
+    """
+
+    def check_results(self,
+                      global_bear,
+                      results,
+                      filename=None,

+
+        assert isinstance(self, BaseTestHelper)
+        assert isinstance(
+            global_bear, GlobalBear), 'The given bear is not a global bear.'
+        assert isinstance(
+            results, list), 'The given results are not a list.'
+
+        bear_output = get_results(global_bear,
+                                  filename=filename,
+                                  settings=settings)
+        if not check_order:

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

$ coala
Executing section all...

In this case, IMO you should run that bear on a testing file. The best case would be you do a comparison between the results before & after your change.

Oh!
I did coala --show-bears --filter-by-language SCSS, before CSSCombBear was not appearing, after the change it was appearing in that list. That's what i thought expanding the languages means.
The other thing in the issue was
filename be given on the command line, and not use stdin, for that

comments.bodyText: Can anybody help in knowing why this Travis build has failed as i just changed the markdown file.Also here i am getting a update branch option should i click that ? Although i had rebased my branch with upstream.
Hi @Dhiraj240, thanks for the PR! Check out this link to learn more about proper commit format (improper commit format will cause the builds to fail). Also, make sure to squash your commits into one!
@andrewda Okay, i will do it accordingly.
Ping @Dhiraj240 .
@jayvdb sorry, i had just joined my college after insem break so i was caught up with my college sessions.I will do the proper commit by morning.
@jayvdb Sorry for delay i was attending hackathon during last few days,i hope i did the proper commit but still travis yelled at me.

@Dhiraj240 if you scroll to the bottom of the Travis message, it provides some helpful hints on how to fix any problems. In this case:
**** GitCommitBear [Section: commit | Severity: NORMAL] ****
!    ! Shortlog of HEAD commit isn't in imperative mood! Bad words are 'Added'

You should be using the imperative tense in your commit message (documented here), so say Add StackOverflow tag instead of Added StackOverflow tag. This is the typical format for a Git commit message.
@andrewda thank you , its done.
@li-boxuan I have done some changes as per your review and look what is this as i had tweaked just a markdown.
Can anybody help me what all this is happening?

comments.bodyText:
Thanks @mikebmc , that change is good of course.
Could you amend your commit so that the commit message complies with https://coala.io/commit .  Otherwise the bots go mad and dont let us merge it.
Also you need to remove the trailing whitespace from the line you edited.  again, unhappy bots.

@jayvdb thanks! I'd noticed the errors on my way out the door yesterday, but didn't have time to correct them. Travis yelled at me again, but also passed the test? I think the issue is that I failed to use --force in an intermediary push, and it auto generated a commit with too long a message. I will look into fixing that this afternoon.
I'd forgotten about gizoogle. Should I look into why that test can't connect?

Dont worry about gizoogle ; our bots sometimes cant get a network connection happening to all the links in the repo.  It has had a lot of development without a release lately, but with GSoC over I think we'll get a bit of release management happening.
You have four commits in https://github.com/coala/corobo/pull/618/commits
You'll need to squash them into one commit.  https://coala.io/git may be of some help.  If you're stuck, come onto https://coala.io/chat and we'll step through the process.  But please dont close the PR and start a new one, delete your fork or delete your branch.  A PR is always fixable until you, and to be useful in coala you need those skills, and we'll happily help you get those skills - but we dont want to keep getting PRs from developers who dont keep their work tidy, as that creates continual work for maintainers and makes it harder to review patches.

Great.  Final step...
The commit message needs to comply with https://coala.io/commit .
Note this is a Closes , not a Fixes , as it isnt a bug.
@jayvdb thanks for your patience! Hopefully this last commit is up to snuff
Ack 7ec1088

then stop responding to users other than those
in the REQUIRED_USERS list in config.

comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,66 @@
+import yaml
+
+
+class DictionaryTagger(object):
+    def __init__(self, dictionary_paths):
+        files = [open(path, 'r') for path in dictionary_paths]
+        dictionaries = [yaml.load(dict_file) for dict_file in files]
+        map(lambda x: x.close(), files)
+        self.dictionary = {}
+        self.max_key_size = 0
+        for curr_dict in dictionaries:
+            for key in curr_dict:
+                if key in self.dictionary:
+                    self.dictionary[key].extend(curr_dict[key])
+                else:
+                    self.dictionary[key] = curr_dict[key]
+                    self.max_key_size = max(self.max_key_size, len(key))
+
+    def tag(self, postagged_sentences):
+        return [self.tag_sentence(sentence) for sentence in postagged_sentences]
+
+    def tag_sentence(self, sentence, tag_with_lemmas=False):
+        """
+        the result is only one tagging of all the possible ones.
+        The resulting tagging is determined by these two priority rules:
+            - longest matches have higher priority
+            - search is made from left to right
+        """
+        tag_sentence = []
+        N = len(sentence)
+        if self.max_key_size == 0:
+            self.max_key_size = N
+        i = 0
+        while (i < N):
+            j = min(i + self.max_key_size, N)  # avoid overflow
+            tagged = False
+            while (j > i):
+                expression_form = ' '.join([word[0]
+                    for word in sentence[i:j]]).lower()
+                expression_lemma = ' '.join(
+                    [word[1] for word in sentence[i:j]]).lower()

+from gitter.splitter import Splitter
+from gitter.pos_tagger import POSTagger

+
+
+def tagged_sentences(text):
+    """
+    Tag a message with dict_tagged_sentence.

+    send by the newcomer and then it split it into list of lists
+    of words using the Splitter class, and it uses POSTagger class
+    to tag each word with pos. And then it uses the DictionaryTagger
+    class and the two dict 'gitter/question.yml' and 'gitter/ignore.yml'
+    and tag the pos tagged word with 'question' or 'ignore'.
+
+    :param text: a string representing the message.
+                 e.g. 'How to solve this issue?'
+    :return: a list of words tagged with DictTagger and POSTagger.
+             e.g. [[('how', 'how', ['question', 'WRB']),
+                    ('can', 'can', ['MD']),
+                    ('I', 'I', ['PRP']),
+                    ('solve', 'solve', ['VB']),
+                    ('this', 'this', ['DT']),
+                    ('issue', 'issue', ['NN']),
+                    ('?', '?', ['question', '.'])]]
+    """
+    splitter = Splitter()
+    postagger = POSTagger()
+    splitted_sentences = splitter.split(text)
+    pos_tagged_sentences = postagger.pos_tag(splitted_sentences)
+    dicttagger = DictionaryTagger(['gitter/question.yml', 'gitter/ignore.yml'])

@@ -0,0 +1,62 @@
+from gitter.splitter import Splitter
+from gitter.pos_tagger import POSTagger
+from gitter.dict_tagger import DictionaryTagger
+
+
+def tagged_sentences(text):
+    """
+    Tag a message with dict_tagged_sentence.
+
+    This method takes a string parameter which is the message
+    send by the newcomer and then it split it into list of lists
+    of words using the Splitter class, and it uses POSTagger class
+    to tag each word with pos. And then it uses the DictionaryTagger
+    class and the two dict 'gitter/question.yml' and 'gitter/ignore.yml'
+    and tag the pos tagged word with 'question' or 'ignore'.
+
+    :param text: a string representing the message.
+                 e.g. 'How to solve this issue?'
+    :return: a list of words tagged with DictTagger and POSTagger.
+             e.g. [[('how', 'how', ['question', 'WRB']),
+                    ('can', 'can', ['MD']),
+                    ('I', 'I', ['PRP']),
+                    ('solve', 'solve', ['VB']),
+                    ('this', 'this', ['DT']),
+                    ('issue', 'issue', ['NN']),
+                    ('?', '?', ['question', '.'])]]
+    """
+    splitter = Splitter()
+    postagger = POSTagger()
+    splitted_sentences = splitter.split(text)
+    pos_tagged_sentences = postagger.pos_tag(splitted_sentences)
+    dicttagger = DictionaryTagger(['gitter/question.yml', 'gitter/ignore.yml'])
+    dict_tagged_sentences = dicttagger.tag(pos_tagged_sentences)
+    return dict_tagged_sentences
+
+
+def value_of(sentiment):
+    """
+    Get a value based on the sentiment.
+
+    :param sentiment: a string representing the sentiment of
+                      a word. i.e. 'ignore' or 'question'.
+    :return: an integer representing the value of the sentiment.
+    """
+    if sentiment == 'ignore':
+        return 1
+    if sentiment == 'question':
+        return -1
+    return 0

issue.title: openhub/data.py: Convert data dict to list
issue.body:
This checks if type of 'data' is not list then
convert it into list, as 'data1' is a list
and to concatenate 'data' into 'data1', 'data'
must be a list.
Closes #151

Hey @li-boxuan, could have a look at this one again :)

This is a bug; the commit message should use Fixes ..
Also why?  see #151 (comment)

It's returning dict when one and only data is being fetched from the last page.
#152 (comment)

An upstream bug is not solved by hiding it without any explanation.
#152 (comment)
I still need to see what is happening with the pages being removed in the second commit.

We need to find what is causing the problem.
/model/openhub/portfolio_projects/ is prettier than /openhub/ , so I would prefer removing the latter.

We need to find what is causing the problem.

All the testing I have done verifies that it's the number of pages we are deploying as in the master branch we don't have any data at ../affiliated_committers/ and this issue solves that problem, that's why the master branch is not failing and this pr is failing.
So, I tried removing the deploy of other pages like ../outside_committers/, .../outside_projects/, ../portfolio_projects, one by one, to verify that there is not any problem in any of the views, and the netlify passes when any of them is removed.

/model/openhub/portfolio_projects/ is prettier than /openhub/ , so I would prefer removing the latter.

At /openhub/ we are deploying only one page and at /model/openhub/portfolio_projects/ we are deploying almost 40 that's why netlify is not passing in this case.
Having said that we do not know why netlify faling when number of pages is increased? Because as said by @jayvdb,

ciptamedia.org is on netlify with many thousands of pages

So, it may not be the number of pages.
Try changing how portfolio_projects/ is created, e.g. limiting to only 10 projects.

This fix allows contributors to work, but that causes problems.  We are not really sure what is the cause.  But the cause is not portfolio_projects/ as that works currently.  The cause of the new problem is contributors.  So, ....
On your own netlify and on a separate branch, not linked to any PR, limit how many contributors are returned in the list.  try 5.  does that work?  Keep going up until you find when it breaks.
Are contributors linked to portfolio_projects?  If so, maybe the problem is contributors linked to portfolio_projects creates some sort of problem.
It could be crazy: one contributor in all of the contributors somehow causes something to break.
It is very strange you say it works on your machine and breaks on Netlify.  Maybe it is Python version related?  Or a package version is different on your machine vs Netlify ?

The cause of the new problem is contributors. So, ....

@jayvdb, I am not sure about this as all the affiliated_committers are deployed in this pr when removing portfolio_projects.
After including portfolio_projects, Netlify breaks after deploying more than 10 affiliated_committers.

limit how many contributors are returned in the list. try 5. does that work? Keep going up until you find when it breaks.

No, affiliated_committers are nowhere linked to portfolio_projects

Are contributors linked to portfolio_projects?

I am not sure about this as all the affiliated_committers are deployed in this pr when removing portfolio_projects.

That is useful info when triaging this bug.

After including portfolio_projects, Netlify breaks after deploying more than 10 affiliated_committers.

Change which 11 are deployed first.
Maybe there is something special about the 11th.
How many total pages are there in the site now?  how many affiliated_committers pages total?  how many portfolio_projects pages total?

..Maybe there is something special about the 11th....

I tested it with 11-to-15 and 15-to-21 netlify is passing.

How many total pages are there in the site now?..

There are total  294 pages in the site, here is the record of them all:
affiliated_committers : 21
portfolio_projects: 35
outside_projects: 178
outside_committers: 44
others: 16

If I deploy all the affiliated_committers, portfolio_projects breaks Netlify after 23 pages, it means that the Netlify is able to deploy 282 pages, And when I deploy all the portfolio_projects, affiliated_committers breaks Netlify after 11 pages, it means that Netlify is able to deploy 284 pages in this case.

+        'https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/archive/2017/organizations',
+    ]
+
+    def parse(self, response):
+        home_url = "https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/archive/2017/organizations/"
+        selector = "//li[contains(.,'{org_name}')]/a/@href".format(org_name = org_name)
+        organization_link = response.xpath(selector)
+        
+        if(organization_link):
+            organization_link = organization_link[0].extract().split("/")[4]
+        else:
+            error = "No GSoC data for organization '{org_name}'".format(org_name = org_name)
+            item =  {
+                        'name': error
+                    }
+            error_data = {}
+            error_data[0] = item
+            error_data = OrderedDict(sorted(error_data.items(), key=lambda t: t[0]))
+            with open(os.path.join('_site', 'org_info.yaml'), 'w') as f:
+                yaml.dump(error_data, f)
+            return
+
+        follow_link = home_url + organization_link
+        yield response.follow(follow_link, self.parse_org)
+
+    def parse_org(self, response):        
+        project_url = "https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/archive/2017/projects/"
+        technology = {}
+
+        id = response.url.split("/")[-2]
+        org_name = response.css("h3.banner__title::text")[0].extract()
+        org_tagline = response.css("h4.org__tagline::text")[0].extract()
+        org_long_description = response.xpath("//div[@class='org__long-description']")[0].extract()
+        org_technologies = response.xpath(".//div[@class='org__meta']/div[contains(.,"
+                            "'Technologies')]/ul/li/text()").extract()
+         
+        count = 0
+        for tech in org_technologies:
+            technology['%s'% str(count)] = tech
+            count = count + 1
+        
+        item =  {
+                    'id': id,
+                    'name': org_name,
+                    'tagline': org_tagline,
+                    'description': org_long_description,
+                    'technologies': technology
+                }
+        org_data = {}
+        org_data[int(item['id'])] = item
+        org_data = OrderedDict(sorted(org_data.items(), key=lambda t: t[0]))
+        
+        with open(os.path.join('_site', 'org_info.yaml'), 'w') as f:
+            yaml.dump(org_data, f)
+        
+        empty_data = {}
+        # Overwrite any previous data with empty dataset
+        with open(os.path.join('_site', 'project_info.yaml'), 'w') as f:
+            yaml.dump(empty_data, f)
+
+        for res in response.css("a.archive-project-card__link"):
+            link = res.xpath("@href").extract()[0]
+            link = link.split("/")[4]
+            url_project = project_url + link
+            yield response.follow(url_project, self.parse_project)
+
+    def parse_project(self, response):
+        mentors = []
+        org_url = "https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/archive/2017/organizations/"

comments.bodyText:
Redo your commit; it should be one commit.
Read these 2 guidelines.
https://coala.io/commit
https://coala.io/git

Ideally a PR shouldn't come from your master branch it can complicate things.
But don't worry, do not close this one. You can discuss about it in our chat.

done all the requested changes @blazeu
Please review README.md and let me know
Also @learneradarsh I suggest you rebase and squash your commits too. If you need help with that ping us on zulip/gitter for help. There are 3 PRs for this, close the 2 irrelevant ones.
Git rebase and squash done
It seems your commits still 13. Rebase and squash should made the commit into 1.

@learneradarsh Still 2 commits squash them please, btw never press the update branch button, it will always create an extra commit. To sync your branch with coala's master do the rebase locally and force push to avoid creation of extra commits.

Finally, it's done within one commit.
Please review it and let me know about changes(:

You're rebase went awry, and you've somehow integrated the changes of the other ~7 commits that happened after you opened this pr. Don't worry, this is easily fixable. First, do git reset HEAD^ /path/to/file/ for each file that shouldn't be in you commit. Next do git commit --amend to update you commit. After that you can rebase properly from cli using our instructions.

ping @learneradarsh , GCI is over, but the opportunity to learn continues ;-)
Come onto our Zulip or our Gitter room and someone will step you through fixing this PR.
I've manually fixed this PR.

issue.title: scrape.js: Deleted duplicated API call
issue.body:
The created_issues were called twice unnecessarily. This commit deleted one to remove duplicated call
Closes #116

comments.bodyText: Squash your commits into one. You shouldn't have a merge commit.

issue.title: Main.css: Fix broken social link Fixes https://github.com/coala/gci-leaders/issues/73
issue.body: Fixes #73 using @wisn suggestion.

comments.bodyText: @newbazz What would be the appropriate changes to the commit? This is my first PR, I apologise any mistake on common guidelines.
You forgot to put Fixes https://github.com/coala/gci-leaders/issues/73 on your commit body
@newbazz Not sure if it's done right now or if it should be just #73 to reference the issue on commit message.
in two different line
@newbazz Thanks! Please check if it's correct now, apparently I mistook the PR title with the commit message.

coala says:
|    | [NORMAL] GitCommitBear:
|    | No newline found between shortlog and body at HEAD commit. Please add one.

Your commit needs to be like this
Main.css: Fix broken social link

Fixes https://github.com/coala/gci-leaders/issues/73

1 newline between shortlog and body.
@newbazz It should be ok now, GitCommitBear ran without warnings.
I implemented wisn's suggestion, the one that made the issue a newcomer one, but perhaps there are better ways to solve this issue.

issue.title: Add logos to navbar and dashboard
issue.body:
This update shows the organisation or owner logo in kanban board navbar
and repositories on dashboard.
Closes #100

comments.bodyText: Is this a trick or supported by GitHub officially?

I believe this is sort of a trick.
Got this from StackOverflow
This trick is from this video posted by GitHub itself.
I haven't found any official documentation as I believe this is a trick provided by GitHub itself.
I felt this would be a better way since we do not have to make additional API requests for GitHub profile logos.
Cool trick.

issue.title: Make code examples on homepage bookmarkable
issue.body:
Add lang parameter to the URL
Fixes #277

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText: I'm not sure about scrolling to the code example. Assume that someone chooses some language, scrolls up and than bookmarks the URL. In that case it would be strange if after clicking the bookmarked link the page would scroll to the code example.

Great.  You've found the button and changed it.
However, we avoid inline styles.
where is the times new roman coming from?
note that bears-icon-small and similar are defined in http://github.com/coala/coalaCSS
Probably the fix needs to occur there.
And probably the solution is not adding Roboto to bears-icon-small, but requires finding why Times New Roman is being inherited and globally disabling it at the root of the problem.

comments.bodyText:
The root of the problem here is the .fa class of the font awesome icon. Since the "ADD BEAR" text has been written within the  tag, the style "font-family: FontAwesome" automatically gets applied to the text.
At present only the:
h1,
h2,
h3,
h4,
h5,
h6 {
font-family: Roboto;
}
style is the best option from the http://github.com/coala/coalaCSS file to apply the Roboto font-family to the text. But this causes the styles of the materialize.css file heading tags to be applied automatically too.

We can define in a new class in the CoalaCSS file to attend to this particular issue. What do you suggest?

comments.bodyText: What about if we changed the order of the CSS files, like moving FA https://github.com/coala/landing-frontend/blob/master/index.html#L35 before coalaCSS ?
What about moving the text outside of the icon? that's usually the way its done.

Adding a new class to CoalaCSS and moving the text outside the tag does the job. For the time being I added a new class to local copy of CoalaCSS to get the results here: If this approach is okay how can I add the new class to CoalaCSS hosted on Github? Also what should I name it?
I agree with @blazeu, you should try moving the button text out of the i tag. Fontawesome does not expect for the button label to be inside icon's tag.

Here, I moved the label text into parent anchor tag from the tag supposed to be used for icon and the results are satisfactory: ADD BEAR If you want to have bold label then add a new class called bold to coalaCSS and apply it to the parent anchor tag here.
@ksdme yes it works. Sorry I couldn't get to this solution quick. What should I do to my PR for coalaCSS now? Should I delete it and create a new one?
You can let it be open for now, when this PR gets merged without any changes being required in coalaCSS we can have that closed. Please keep it open for now.
